column1: Words

直ちに (tadachi ni): immediately, at once, promptly. Used to express urgency or immediacy of an action or situation. 
・直ちに返事をした。He replied immediately. 
・直ちに出発しましょう。Let’s leave promptly. 
・直ちに解決しなければならない。It must be resolved immediately.

取り敢えず (toriaezu): for the time being, for now, first of all. Used to indicate a temporary or provisional action or situation or to emphasize the priority of something. 
・取り敢えず安心しました。I felt relieved for now. 
・取り敢えず食べ物を買いに行こう。Let’s go buy some food for the time being. 
・取り敢えずこれで終わりにしましょう。Let’s end it here for the time being.

先ず (mazu): first, firstly, to begin with. Used to indicate the order or sequence of actions or events or to introduce a topic or argument. 
・先ず名前を教えてください。Please tell me your name first. 
・先ずは準備から始めましょう。Let’s start with the preparation first. 
・先ず私の考えを聞いてください。To begin with, please listen to my opinion.

勿論 (mochiron): of course, naturally, certainly. Used to express agreement, affirmation or obviousness of a statement or question. 
・勿論行きますよ。Of course I’ll go. 
・勿論それは嘘です。That is naturally a lie. 
・勿論彼は知っています。He certainly knows.

ぴったり (pittari): exactly, perfectly, snugly. Used to describe something that fits or matches exactly or perfectly or something that happens at an exact time or place. 
・この服はぴったりです。This clothes fit perfectly. 
・この箱にぴったり入ります。It fits snugly in this box. 
・彼はぴったり正午に到着した。He arrived exactly at noon.

多分 (tabun): maybe, perhaps, probably. Used to express uncertainty, possibility or probability of something. 
・多分雨が降るでしょう。It will probably rain. 
・多分彼は忙しいのでしょう。Maybe he is busy. 
・多分明日会いましょう。Let’s see each other tomorrow perhaps.

到頭 (toutou): at last, in the end, finally. Used to express the final outcome or result of something, often with a negative or disappointing tone. 
・彼は到頭失敗した。He failed in the end. 
・到頭彼女は彼を捨てた。She finally dumped him. 
・到頭何もできなかった。I couldn’t do anything at last.

先ほど (sakihodo): a while ago, just now, earlier. Used to indicate a recent past time or event, usually within the same day or conversation. 
・先ほどお話した人です。He is the person I talked to just now. 
・先ほど電話がありました。There was a phone call a while ago. 
・先ほどのニュースを見ましたか。Did you see the news earlier?

はっきり (hakkiri): clearly, distinctly, definitely. Used to describe something that is clear or definite in terms of appearance, sound, meaning or attitude. 
・はっきりと決めました。I decided definitely. 
・はっきり言ってください。Please say it clearly. 
・彼の声がはっきり聞こえた。I heard his voice distinctly.

決して (kesshite): never, by no means, not at all. Used to express a strong negation or denial of something, usually followed by a negative verb form. 
・彼は決して嘘をつきません。He never lies. 
・決してあきらめないでください。Please never give up. 
・これは決して忘れられない思い出です。This is a memory that I will never forget.

単に (tanni): simply, merely, only. Used to indicate that something is simple or plain without any additional or special factors or reasons. 
・これは単に偶然の一致です。This is simply a coincidence. 
・単に好奇心から聞いたのです。I asked simply out of curiosity. 
・彼は単に遅刻しただけではなく無断欠席もした。He not only came late but also skipped without permission.

まれに (mare ni): rarely, seldom, occasionally. Used to describe something that happens very infrequently or with a low probability. 
・彼はまれに笑う。He seldom smiles. 
・まれに地震が起こる。Earthquakes occur rarely. 
・まれに彼女から手紙が来る。I occasionally receive letters from her.

すっかり (sukkari): completely, totally, entirely. Used to emphasize the completeness or totality of something, such as a change, a recovery or a loss. 
・すっかり忘れていた。I had entirely forgotten. 
・風邪がすっかり治った。I have totally recovered from the cold. 
・彼はすっかり変わってしまった。He has completely changed.

丸で (marude): just like, as if, completely. Used to make a comparison or a contrast between two things or to emphasize the completeness or extremity of something. 
・彼は丸で子供のようだ。He is just like a child. 
・丸で無駄な努力だった。It was a completely futile effort. 
・丸で夢を見ているみたいだ。It’s as if I’m dreaming.

いきなり (ikinari): suddenly, all of a sudden. Used to describe something that happens abruptly without any prior warning or reason. 
・いきなり彼女にプロポーズした。He suddenly proposed to her. 
・いきなり雨が降り出したので。It suddenly started raining so. 
・いきなり怒って部屋を出て行った。He suddenly got angry and left the room.

一杯 (ippai): full, a lot, a glass. Used to mean that something is full or filled up that something is done a lot or to the fullest or that a glass or cup of something is drunk. 
・この箱は一杯です。This box is full. 
・一杯勉強しました。I studied a lot. 
・一杯飲みましょう。Let’s have a drink.

散々 (sanzan): severely, terribly, badly. Used to describe something that is done or experienced in a severe or terrible way, often with a negative connotation. 
・彼は散々叱られた。He was scolded severely. 
・散々な目にあった。I had a bad experience. 
・散々迷ってから決めた。I decided after wandering terribly.

凡そ (oyoso): about, approximately, roughly. Used to indicate an approximate or rough amount or degree of something, often followed by a number or a quantity. 
・凡そ10分で着きます。I will arrive in about 10 minutes. 
・凡そ1000円で買えます。You can buy it for roughly 1000 yen. 
・凡そ半分の人が賛成した。Approximately half of the people agreed.

すごく (sugoku): very, extremely, terribly. Used to emphasize the degree or intensity of something, often followed by an adjective or an adverb. 
・すごく痛いです。It hurts terribly. 
・すごく楽しかったです。It was very fun. 
・すごく速く走った。He ran extremely fast.

上手く (umaku): well, skillfully, successfully. Used to describe something that is done or achieved in a good or satisfactory way, often followed by a verb. 
・彼は上手くギターを弾く。He plays the guitar well. 
・彼女は上手く嘘をついた。She lied skillfully. 
・上手く話し合いましょう。Let’s talk things over successfully.

直接 (chokusetsu): directly, personally, immediately. Used to indicate that something is done or experienced without any intermediaries, delays or detours. 
・直接会いに行った。I went to see him directly. 
・直接電話してください。Please call me personally. 
・この道を直接行けば駅に着きます。If you take this road directly, you will reach the station.

昔 (mukashi): long ago, in the past, formerly. Used to refer to a distant or vague past time or event, often in stories or reminiscences. 
・昔は違っていた。It was different in the past.
・昔の話を聞かせてください。Please tell me a story from the past. 
・昔この地には城があった。Long ago, there was a castle in this land.

嘗て (katsute): once, formerly, ever. Used to indicate that something happened or existed in the past but not anymore, often with a sense of nostalgia or regret. 
・嘗て私は彼を愛していた。I loved him formerly. 
・嘗て彼は有名な歌手だった。He was once a famous singer. 
・嘗てこんなに美しかったのか。Was it ever so beautiful?

まあまあ (maamaa): so-so, not bad, fairly. Used to express a moderate or average degree or quality of something, often as a response to a question or a comment. 
・今日の天気はまあまあです。The weather today is not bad. 
・まあまあ、落ち着いてください。So-so, please calm down. 
・あなたの日本語はまあまあですね。Your Japanese is fairly good.

また (mata): again, also, or. Used to mean that something is repeated or continued, that something is added or additional or that something is alternative or conditional. 
・また来てください。Please come again. 
・また彼は医者です。Also, he is a doctor. 
・また明日会いましょう。Let’s meet again tomorrow.
